title: What really matters at the end of life | BJ Miller

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's experience that led to his formal relationship with death?

options.label: A
options.text: He was in a car accident.

options.label: B
options.text: He climbed atop a parked commuter train and was electrocuted.

options.label: C
options.text: He was diagnosed with a terminal illness.

options.label: D
options.text: He witnessed a death in his family.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main reason why the healthcare system is not serving people well?

options.label: A
options.text: It is understaffed.

options.label: B
options.text: It is overbudgeted.

options.label: C
options.text: It was designed with diseases, not people, at its center.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not technology-driven.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key distinction between necessary and unnecessary suffering, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Necessary suffering is the suffering that we can change, while unnecessary suffering is the suffering that we cannot change.

options.label: B
options.text: Necessary suffering is the suffering that is a natural part of life, while unnecessary suffering is the suffering that is caused by the healthcare system.

options.label: C
options.text: Necessary suffering is the suffering that is caused by the healthcare system, while unnecessary suffering is the suffering that is a natural part of life.

options.label: D
options.text: Necessary suffering is the suffering that is caused by external factors, while unnecessary suffering is the suffering that is caused by internal factors.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's idea of a "shift in perspective" and how does it relate to death?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a change in one's attitude towards death, from fear to acceptance.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a change in one's perspective on life, from focusing on what is lacking to appreciating what one has.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a change in one's perspective on death, from seeing it as a burden to seeing it as a natural part of life.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a change in one's perspective on the meaning of life, from focusing on material possessions to focusing on spiritual growth.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's idea of "play" in relation to dying and how does it relate to the concept of beneficence?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a way of distracting oneself from the pain of dying.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a way of creating something new and meaningful with the fact of dying.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a way of ignoring the reality of dying.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a way of hastening the process of dying.

title: Cannibalism in the animal kingdom - Bill Schutt

options.label: B

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: Why do some species, like the spadefoot toad, engage in cannibalism?

options.text: To avoid starvation or extreme stress.

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce competition and cull the weak, promoting the survival of the species.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: To communicate with other members of their species.

options.text: They produce a small number of eggs and adults exhibit individual recognition of their offspring.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are trying to reduce competition among their offspring.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are trying to increase their reproductive success.

options.label: D

title: Are you a giver or a taker? - Adam Grant

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is a key characteristic of a "taker"?

options.label: C
options.text: They are critical and skeptical.

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Pronoia; it's not related to a culture of givers.

options.label: B
options.text: Pronoia; a culture of givers actually turns paranoia upside down.

options.label: C
options.text: Paranoia; it's a culture of givers that turns paranoia upside down.

options.label: D
options.text: Paranoia; a culture of givers does not relate to this concept.

multiple-choice.question: B: They are self-serving in their interactions.
C: Making a small effort to add value to someone's life.
B: By weeding out takers and making it safe for givers to ask for help.
C: Getting to know people's values and intentions.
B: Pronoia; a culture of givers actually turns paranoia upside down.
